newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - May 16.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - May 16.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Govt fights back in war against baht. Finance Minister Amnuay Viravan last night declared war on "outside plunders" he blamed for baht and stock crises, and his beligerence was underscored by fierce and sucessful Thai counter-attacks on foreign money speculators who suffered massive losses.

Dismissing speculation that he might resign, Amnuay said upon returning from Japan that foreign speculators were using the local media to spread rumours to destroy local and international confidence in the Thai economy. (The Nation)
- Regional markets hit by baht crisis. Stock prices plunged across Southeast Asia yesterday as investors spooked by the baht crisis pulled funds out of the region's markets.
Rising fears that Thailand's financial woes currencies triggered heavy selling pressure, which led to a domino effect across Asia, analysts and traders said. (BANGKOK POST)

- Assets at root of disagreement. The planned merger between Thai Danu Bank and finance One Plc has been delayed again as both sides go over the complexities of the finance company's sub-standard assets.
The Bank's board yesterday deferred making a decision on whether to takover the finance company as proposed by the Bank of Thailand after talks came to a standstill. (BANGKOK POST BUSINESS)
- SET further slides on fears of baht attack. The struggling stock market nose dived to 544.10 points yesterday, a near eight years low, on growing fears of another baht attack.
Yesterday the stock market shed 27.20 points before managing to finish the day only 13.43 points lower at 557.87 on volume of Bt6.63 billion. (THE NATION BUSINESS)
